section.title: Font
section.para: Select the font and font size used to display the text in the main window panes.

important.para: OmegaT uses the same font for both the source and target languages. If you work in a language pair that uses different writing systems, make sure you choose a font that can display both languages correctly. Characters that are not supported will appear as squares.

section.title: File Filters
section.para: This dialog lists the available file filters. Filters used in the current project are displayed in bold. If you prefer not to use OmegaT to translate files of a certain type, you can turn off the corresponding filter by unchecking its check box. OmegaT will then omit the corresponding files when loading projects, and copy them unmodified to the target folder when creating target documents. Just tick the check box to start using the filter again. Click the Restore Defaults button to reset the file filters to their default settings. You can edit the file types and corresponding encoding covered by a filter by selecting it in the list and clicking the Edit... button.
Modified file filter preferences are saved in , in the configuration folder. See for details.
You can also enable project specific file filters in . Doing so will put the in the project folder. See for details.
The dialog allows you to enable or disable the following general options for all files:

listitem.para: Remove leading and trailing tags: Uncheck this option to display all tags, including those at the beginning and end of the segment.

warning.para: Do not put any text before the first tag if all tags are displayed for Microsoft Open XML formats (.docx, .xlsx, etc.)—it is a technical tag that must always begin the segment.

listitem.para: Remove leading and trailing whitespace in non-segmented projects: By default, OmegaT removes any leading and trailing whitespace. In non-segmented projects, you can uncheck this option to retain that whitespace.
Preserve spaces for all tags: check this option if the source documents contain significant spaces that are used to control the layout and must not be ignored.

Ignore file context when identifying segments with alternate translations: By default, OmegaT uses the source file name as one of the elements that identify an alternative translation. If this option is checked, the source file name is not used, and alternative translations will apply in every file as long as the remaining identifying elements (previous/next segments, or a segment identifier, depending on the file format) matches.

section.title: Edit
section.para: This dialog enables you to specify the source filename patterns for files to be processed by the filter, customize the filenames of translated files and select the encoding used for each file type when loading the source file and saving the translation. You can modify a file filter pattern either by typing directly in the fields or clicking the Edit... button. Click the Add... button to add a new file filter pattern. Adding and editing use the same dialog to define patterns. It includes a special target filename pattern editor that lets you customize how output files are named.

section.title: Source filename pattern
section.para: OmegaT attempts to select a filter based on the extension of the file loaded from the project’s source folder. More precisely, it attempts to match the source filename patterns in each filter against the filename. For example, the pattern .xhtml matches any file with the *.xhtml extension. If an appropriate filter is found, the file is assigned to it for processing. For example, by default, the XHTML filter is used to process files with the .xhtml extension. You can change or add filename patterns to specify what files are handled by an individual filter. Source filename patterns use wild card characters similar to those used in Searches. The “*” character matches zero or more characters, while the “?” character matches exactly one character. All other characters are interpreted as is. For example, if you want to have the text filter handle readme files (readme, read.me, or readme.txt) you can use the pattern read*.

section.title: Source and translated file encoding
section.para: A limited number of file formats specify a mandatory encoding. For other file formats, the encoding you specify for the extension that matches their name will be used. For example, .txt files will be loaded using the default encoding of your operating system if no other encoding is specified. You can change the source encoding for each different source filename pattern. Target files can also be written using any encoding. By default, the encoding of the translated file is the same as that of the source file. The source and target encoding fields use drop-down menus listing all supported encodings. Selecting the <auto> option leaves the choice of encoding to OmegaT, based on the criteria below.

listitem.para: OmegaT uses the encoding declaration in the source file, if present, to identify the encoding (HTML or XML based files).
OmegaT is instructed to use a mandatory encoding for certain file formats (Java properties, for example).
OmegaT uses the default encoding of the operating system for text files.

section.title: Translated filename
section.para: You may want to rename the files you translate automatically, by adding a language code after the file name, for example. The target filename pattern uses a special syntax. The easiest way to modify this field is to click the Edit... button and use the Edit Pattern dialog. You can also modify the name directly in the target filename pattern field of the file filters dialog. If you want to revert to the default filter configuration after making changes, click the Restore Defaults button. Your changes only take effect after you click the OK button to close the Edit Filter dialog. The Edit Pattern dialog offers various options. A non-exhaustive list is presented below.

listitem.para: ${filename}—The default pattern. It represents the complete filename of the source file, including the extension. Using this pattern assigns the translated file the exact same name as the source file.
${nameOnly}— Inserts just the name of the source file, without the extension.
${extension} —Inserts the original file extension.
${targetLocale}—Inserts the target locale code (in “xx_YY” format).
${targetLanguage}—Inserts the target language and country code together (in “xx-YY” format).
${targetLanguageCode}—Inserts only the target language code (“xx”).
${targetCountryCode}—Inserts only the target country code (“YY”).
${timestamp-????}—Inserts the system date time when the file is created. Various date and time patterns are available.
See the Oracle documentation for examples of the SimpleDateFormat patterns.
${system-os-name}—Inserts the name of operating system used to create the file.
${system-user-name}—Inserts the user’s login name.
${system-host-name}—Inserts the host name assigned to the system.
${file-source-encoding}—Inserts the encoding of the source file.
${file-target-encoding}—Inserts the encoding of the target file.
${targetLocaleLCID}—Inserts the Microsoft target locale.

section.title: Language rules
section.para: Only the rules associated to language patterns that correspond to the source language of your project are applied. See in .

For example, for a translation from Japanese, only the rule set associated to the JA.* pattern and the rule sets associated to the .* patterns (those are generic patterns that apply to all languages) will be taken into account.
When you click on a language pattern in the top half of the dialog, a list of associated rules will be displayed in the bottom half of the dialog.

All segmentation rule sets for a matching language pattern are active and are applied in order. Rules for specific language regions should be higher than default ones. For example, the rules for FR-CA should be set higher than those for FR.*, which should themselves be higher than the generic .* set. Thus, when translating from Canadian French the rules for Canadian French—if any—will apply first, followed by the rules for French and lastly, by the generic rules.
If you want to create an empty set of rules for a new language pattern click the Add button.

An empty line will appear at the bottom of the table. Change the name of the rule set and the language pattern to the desired label and corresponding pattern. The language pattern is a regular expression. Use the Move Up button to set the rule set priority.

warning.para: Exception rules should be listed above break rules

listitem.para: Specify text combinations that are exceptions to a break rule. For example, Mrs. Dalloway should not be split in two segments even though a break rule for period followed by a space generally defines a sentence.

Separates the source text into segments. For example, period followed by a space generally defines a sentence end in English.

section.title: Editor

listitem.para: You can have the source text inserted automatically into the editing field. This is useful for texts containing many trademarks or other proper nouns that must be left unchanged.
OmegaT leaves the editing field blank. This option allows you to enter the translation without the need to remove the source text, thus saving you two keystrokes (Select All / Delete).

Empty translations are now allowed. They are displayed as <EMPTY> in the editor pane. To create one, right-click in a segment, and select Set empty translation. The entry Remove translation in the same context menu allows you to delete the existing translation of the current segment. You achieve the same effect by clearing the target segment and pressing the Enter key.
OmegaT automatically inserts the translation of the string most similar to the current source, if it exceeds the similarity threshold you set in this dialog.
The prefix is used to identify translations inserted as fuzzy matches. You can also see the prefix as a to include it in the validation process.
Some scripts are very useful when it comes to matches insertion. See for details.

section.para: The remaining options are described below.

varlistentry.term: Attempt to convert numbers when inserting a fuzzy match

listitem.para: If this option is checked, OmegaT attempts to convert the numbers in the fuzzy matches according to the source contents when a fuzzy match is inserted either manually or automatically. There are a number of restrictions:
The source segment and the fuzzy matches must contain the same list of numbers.
The numbers must be exactly the same between the source and the target matches.
Only integers and simple floats (using the period as a decimal character, e.g., 5.4, but not 5,4 or 54E-01) are considered.

varlistentry.term: Allow translation to be equal to source

listitem.para: The documents to translate may contain trademarks, names, or other proper nouns that will remain the same in the translated versions. There are two strategies to handle segments containing only such unchanging text.

You can decide not to translate such segments at all. OmegaT will then report these segments as not translated. This is the default approach. The alternative is to enter a translation that is identical to the source text. OmegaT can be set to recognize such entries by selecting this option.

varlistentry.term: Export the segment to text files

note.para: Although this function allows segment contents to be exported to text files in a folder named , it has no relation to the feature and only shares a name for historical reasons.

listitem.para: The text export function exports data from within the current OmegaT project to plain text files. The data is exported when the segment is opened. The files appear in the folder of the OmegaT user file folder (see for details), and include:
The content of the segment source text ().
The content of the segment target text ().
The text that has been highlighted by the user before using ().
The content of the files is overwritten either when a new segment is opened or when a new selection is exported.

The files are unformatted plain text files. The whole process can be steered and controlled via Tck/Tcl-based scripting. See Using the OmegaT text export function for specifics, examples and suggestions.
The script does something similar but for the whole project at once. See .

listitem.para: Ticking this check box will cause to stop at each segment with more than one possible translation, irrespective of whether it has already been translated. This allows you to make sure there are no mistranslations.
Leave this option unchecked to prevent any corruption of the tags (such as a partial deletion) during editing. You can still remove a complete tag by deleting it.

listitem.para: You can also use regular expressions to define custom tags.
For example, you can enter \d+ into the field to treat all numbers as tags, enabling you to check that numbers have not been accidentally changed in the translation.
Similarly, you can use <.*?> to make sure that HTML (or similar) tags entered into the source text are preserved without modification in the translation.
You can also combine both of the above custom tags into a single expression: (<.*?>)|(\d+).
When present in a segment target, they are marked in red characters by default and are also identified as extraneous tags for validation purposes. See for details.

section.title: Proxy Login
section.para: If OmegaT needs to use an authenticated proxy server to access the Internet, enter the details provided by the proxy administrator here.

section.title: Secure store
section.para: This option lets you define or reset the master password used to protect login details and access keys for machine translation services. Always make a backup of that information before creating a new password, because they will all be deleted and have to be re-entered.

Additional plugins can be found on the OmegaT development site.
